summary: This is a transcript of a DOJ Office of the Inspector General interview with a former SigNet employee, conducted on September 22, 2021. The interview focuses on the employee's role in responding to a video system failure at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York around the time of Jeffrey Epstein's death in August 2019. The discussion centers on technical issues with the RAID drives, attempts to rebuild them, and the potential impact of the FBI seizing the equipment during the rebuild process.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The investigation is into the circumstances surrounding his death while incarcerated at the MCC.

persons.name: Derek
persons.context: The MCC employee who contacted SigNet about failed RAID drives in the video system and attempted to replace them.

persons.name: Sharom
persons.context: A technical support engineer from Qognify (the video software manufacturer) who provided instructions for rebuilding the RAID array.

persons.name: Barr
persons.context: A SigNet employee, a former Bureau of Prisons com tech, who started with SigNet in February 2019 and may have been involved in the initial handling of the MCC service request.

persons.name: Freds
persons.context: A SigNet sales rep who worked with the Bureau of Prisons and sold their equipment. The witness considered reaching out to him during the incident.

connections.description: The witness, a senior customer support rep for SigNet, provided technical support to Derek at the MCC regarding failed RAID drives in the video system.
Both were SigNet employees. The witness believes Barr may have initially received the service request from Derek and passed it to him because Barr was on vacation.
The witness reached out to Qognify support (Sharom) for assistance with the RAID failure, and Sharom provided step-by-step instructions.
According to the witness's recollection and comments, the FBI arrived at the MCC and confiscated the video recording equipment while Derek was attempting to rebuild the RAID drives.

events.title: Possible Initial Drive Failure
events.description: The OIG agents suggest the RAID drives in the MCC video system may have initially gone bad on this date, though the witness's specific recollection starts later.

events.title: Service Request Created for MCC Video System
events.description: A SigNet service request is created after Derek reports that the RAID has crashed. The witness receives or is assigned to the case and contacts Qognify for support.

events.title: Drives Located but No Access
events.description: Derek locates replacement drives but does not have access to the locked DVR room to install them.

events.title: Drive Rebuild Attempt and FBI Seizure
events.description: Derek gains access to the DVR room, begins replacing drives and attempting a RAID rebuild. The FBI arrives, seizes the entire video recording system, potentially during the rebuild process.

events.title: OIG Interview of Former SigNet Employee
events.description: The Department of Justice Office of the Inspector General conducts a voluntary, recorded telephone interview with a former SigNet employee as part of its investigation into Jeffrey Epstein's death.

keyFacts: The interview is part of the DOJ OIG's investigation into the death of Jeffrey Epstein and the surrounding circumstances.

A critical video system RAID failure occurred at the MCC in early August 2019. The witness's service ticket comments indicate the FBI confiscated the recording equipment on August 10th while drives were being rebuilt, potentially corrupting the video database.

The witness clarifies that if two drives in a RAID 5 configuration fail, all data is lost and the array must be rebuilt from scratch. He also states the MCC system did not have email alerting enabled, so staff would have to manually check for system failures.

There is a discrepancy explored between the service ticket timeline (events concentrated August 8-10) and the witness's personal recollection of being on a weekend camping trip and communicating with Derek.
The OIG agents are interested in the period from July 29, 2019, onward, suggesting the drive issues may have begun earlier than the August 8 service request.
